article.title: An introduction to Topological Data Analysis: fundamental and practical aspects for data scientists

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main motivation for using Topological Data Analysis (TDA)?
choices: Topology and geometry provide a robust approach to infer qualitative and quantitative information about data structure.
TDA offers a replacement for traditional statistical methods in data analysis.
TDA focuses primarily on analyzing complex numerical data.
TDA is solely used for visualization purposes in data science.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the first step in the standard TDA pipeline?
choices: Constructing a simplicial complex from the data.
Extracting topological or geometric information from the data structure.
Obtaining a finite set of points with a notion of distance or similarity.
Applying machine learning tasks on the extracted information.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are some limitations of deterministic approaches in TDA?
choices: They are computationally inefficient and not scalable to large datasets.
They struggle to handle high-dimensional data.
They do not account for the random nature of data and the variability of topological quantities.
They are not able to identify any meaningful topological features.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is NOT a key problem addressed by a statistical approach to TDA?
choices: Selecting relevant scales at which topological phenomena should be considered.
Dealing with outliers and providing robust methods for TDA.
Developing new visualization techniques for topological features.
Providing confidence regions for topological features and discussing their significance.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which statement about the applications of TDA in data science is true?
choices: TDA has only been successfully applied in a limited number of specific fields.
TDA often achieves its best results when combined with other analysis or learning techniques.
TDA is primarily focused on theoretical aspects and lacks practical applications.
TDA is a complete replacement for traditional data science tools.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the Hausdorff distance in TDA?
choices: To measure the similarity between different datasets from different ambient spaces.
To determine the dimensionality of a point cloud.
To quantify the proximity between different datasets from the same ambient metric space.
To identify outliers in a dataset.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the Gromov-Hausdorff distance used for?
choices: To compare the size of two datasets.
To measure how far two metric spaces are from being isometric.
To determine the optimal scale for constructing a simplicial complex.
To identify clusters within a dataset.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key idea in TDA to identify topological features beyond connectivity?
choices: Connecting only pairs of nearby data points.
Using clustering algorithms on neighboring graphs.
Building higher dimensional equivalents of neighboring graphs using simplicial complexes.
Focusing solely on the analysis of distances between data points.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the two key properties of simplicial complexes that make them useful in TDA?
choices: They are both topological and combinatorial.
They are efficient for data visualization and easily interpretable.
They are robust to noise and outliers in data.
They can be used to analyze both continuous and discrete data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the Vietoris-Rips complex and the Čech complex?
choices: The Vietoris-Rips complex connects all data points within a certain distance, while the Čech complex connects points whose balls of a certain radius intersect.
The Vietoris-Rips complex is used for analyzing high-dimensional data, while the Čech complex is used for analyzing low-dimensional data.
The Vietoris-Rips complex is more robust to noise, while the Čech complex is more sensitive to outliers.
The Vietoris-Rips complex is easier to compute, while the Čech complex is more computationally expensive.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the nerve of a cover?
choices: A simplicial complex that represents the intersection patterns between sets in the cover.
A graph that connects the centers of the sets in the cover.
A distance function that measures the proximity between sets in the cover.
A statistical measure that quantifies the overlap between sets in the cover.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the Nerve Theorem state?
choices: If a cover of a topological space satisfies specific conditions, then the nerve of the cover and the union of sets in the cover are homotopy equivalent.
The nerve of any cover is always homeomorphic to the union of sets in the cover.
The nerve of a cover provides a complete and accurate representation of the geometry of the underlying space.
The Nerve Theorem is only applicable to finite sets of points in Euclidean space.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of the Mapper algorithm?
choices: To reconstruct the underlying geometry of a dataset.
To cluster data points based on their topological features.
To summarize and visualize a dataset using the nerve of a refined pull back cover.
To identify outliers in a dataset.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is NOT a common type of function used as a filter in the Mapper algorithm?
choices: Eigenfunctions of graph Laplacians.
Distance function to a given point.
Fourier transform of the data.
Density estimates.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the role of the gain parameter in the cover used for the Mapper algorithm?
choices: It determines the size of the intervals in the cover.
It controls the percentage of overlap between consecutive intervals in the cover.
It sets the number of clusters used for decomposing the preimage of open sets.
It determines the type of clustering algorithm used for the preimage of open sets.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is NOT a common application of the Mapper algorithm in data analysis?
choices: Clustering of data points.
Feature selection.
Dimensionality reduction.
Time series analysis.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the r-offset of a compact subset K in R^d?
choices: The set of all points in R^d that are within distance r from K.
The boundary of K.
The set of all points in K that are within distance r from each other.
The intersection of all balls of radius r centered on points in K.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between the topology of the offsets of a compact set and the Hausdorff distance between the set and a sample of points from the set?
choices: Under certain regularity assumptions, if the Hausdorff distance is small, the offsets of the sample and the set are homotopy equivalent.
The Hausdorff distance has no impact on the topology of the offsets.
The topology of the offsets is always the same, regardless of the Hausdorff distance.
The Hausdorff distance is only used for visualization purposes and does not relate to topological inference.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the space of k-chains on a simplicial complex K?
choices: The set of all k-dimensional simplices in K.
The set of all linear combinations of k-simplices in K with coefficients in Z2.
The set of all k-dimensional holes in K.
The set of all connected components in K.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the kth Betti number of a simplicial complex K?
choices: The number of k-dimensional simplices in K.
The dimension of the kth homology group of K.
The number of connected components in K.
The largest dimension of a simplex in K.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between the homology groups of two simplicial complexes whose geometric realizations are homotopy equivalent?
choices: Their homology groups are isomorphic.
Their homology groups are different.
Their homology groups have the same number of elements.
Their homology groups have no relationship.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main challenge in applying Theorem 3 to estimate Betti numbers from a point cloud?
choices: The computation of the Čech complex is very expensive.
The regularity assumption involving the α-reach of the underlying shape may be too restrictive.
The choice of the scale parameter r for the Čech complex is difficult.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using Theorem 4 to infer the topology of a shape from a point cloud?
choices: It avoids the need to compute the Čech complex.
It provides a more robust approach to handle noise and outliers.
It does not require any regularity assumption on the underlying shape.
It offers a more efficient algorithm for computing Betti numbers.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main drawback of using the Hausdorff distance for topological inference?
choices: It is sensitive to outliers in the data.
It is computationally expensive.
It requires strong regularity assumptions on the underlying shape.
It cannot be used for analyzing high-dimensional data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a filtration of a simplicial complex?
choices: A nested family of subcomplexes.
A collection of simplices that cover the complex.
A function that assigns a real value to each simplex in the complex.
A distance function that measures the proximity between simplices in the complex.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does a persistence barcode encode?
choices: The lifespan of different homological features across a filtration.
The geometry of the underlying shape.
The distances between data points.
The density of the data points.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a persistence diagram?
choices: A multi-set of points in the plane representing the birth and death times of homological features in a filtration.
A barcode representation of persistent homology.
A graph that connects data points based on their topological similarity.
A function that assigns a persistence value to each data point.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between the kth Betti number of a union of balls and its persistence diagram?
choices: The kth Betti number for a given radius is equal to the number of persistence intervals corresponding to k-dimensional features and containing that radius.
The kth Betti number is unrelated to the persistence diagram.
The kth Betti number is the same for all radii in the filtration.
The kth Betti number can only be computed from the persistence diagram for a specific radius.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the advantages of using a persistence diagram to represent the homology of a union of balls?
choices: It provides a multiscale view of the homology across different radii.
It allows to track the evolution of homological features as the radius increases.
It offers a compact and visual representation of persistent homology.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a persistence module?
choices: A sequence of vector spaces connected by linear maps.
A set of persistence intervals.
A multi-set of points in the plane representing a persistence diagram.
A function that assigns a persistence value to each point in a dataset.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a persistence landscape?
choices: A collection of continuous, piecewise linear functions summarizing a persistence diagram.
A visualization of a persistence diagram.
A statistical measure of the variability of a persistence diagram.
A method for computing the distance between persistence diagrams.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using persistence landscapes for statistical analysis?
choices: Persistence landscapes are elements of a Hilbert space, allowing for the application of various statistical learning methods.
Persistence landscapes are more robust to noise and outliers than persistence diagrams.
Persistence landscapes are easier to compute than persistence diagrams.
Persistence landscapes provide a more detailed representation of topological features than persistence diagrams.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the Bottleneck distance between two persistence diagrams?
choices: The maximum distance between corresponding points in the two diagrams under an optimal matching.
The average distance between all points in the two diagrams.
The number of points in the two diagrams that are different.
The sum of the persistence values of all points in the two diagrams.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using the stability theorem for persistence diagrams?
choices: It allows to derive concrete stability results for specific filtrations in TDA.
It provides a way to compute the exact distance between persistence diagrams.
It ensures that persistence diagrams are always unique.
It guarantees that persistence diagrams are robust to changes in the dimension of the data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main limitation of the Bottleneck distance between persistence diagrams?
choices: It is computationally expensive.
It is sensitive to small perturbations in the diagrams.
It is dominated by the largest distance among pairs of points and ignores the closeness of other pairs.
It is not suitable for comparing diagrams with different numbers of points.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of a statistical approach to persistent homology?
choices: To account for the random nature of data and the variability of topological features.
To develop new algorithms for computing persistence diagrams.
To visualize topological features in high-dimensional data.
To identify the optimal scale for constructing a filtration.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a confidence region for a persistence diagram?
choices: A region in the plane that contains the true persistence diagram with a certain probability.
A statistical measure of the variability of the persistence diagram.
A method for identifying significant topological features in the diagram.
A visualization tool for displaying the persistence diagram.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main challenge in defining a mean persistence diagram?
choices: The space of persistence diagrams is not a Hilbert space, making the definition of a mean not straightforward.
Persistence diagrams can have different numbers of points, making it difficult to compare them.
Persistence diagrams are sensitive to noise and outliers.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using subsampling to compute topological signatures for large datasets?
choices: It reduces the computational cost of persistence calculations.
It provides a more robust representation of the data.
It allows to analyze datasets with very high dimension.
It avoids the need to compute persistence diagrams.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the two main applications of TDA in machine learning?
choices: Exploratory data analysis and feature engineering.
Dimensionality reduction and clustering.
Time series analysis and image processing.
Anomaly detection and hypothesis testing.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main challenge in using persistence diagrams directly as features in machine learning algorithms?
choices: Persistence diagrams are highly non-linear, making them unsuitable for many standard algorithms.
Persistence diagrams are sensitive to noise and outliers.
Persistence diagrams are computationally expensive to compute.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the GUDHI library?
choices: To provide efficient algorithms for computing persistent homology and other TDA methods.
To visualize persistence diagrams and other topological representations.
To perform statistical analysis of persistence diagrams.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the bottleneck bootstrap method in the context of protein binding analysis?
choices: To define a confidence band for a persistence diagram based on resampling.
To compare the persistence diagrams of different protein configurations.
To cluster protein configurations based on their topological similarity.
To reduce the dimensionality of the protein data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of using a random forest in the classification of sensor data?
choices: To predict the walker from a high-dimensional set of topological features.
To compute the persistence landscapes of the sensor data.
To visualize the topological features of the sensor data.
To cluster the sensor data based on their topological similarity.
